useCases.title: Habitual Actions
useCases.mainExample: Peter quite often visits his uncle in Italy.
moreExamples: She always drinks coffee in the morning.
They go to the gym three times a week.
He never eats meat.
I usually wake up at 7am.
We sometimes watch TV in the evening.
useCases.notes: Use Present Simple for repeated actions, routines, and habits.

useCases.title: Used with Time Conjunctions
useCases.mainExample: Mrs Rice waters her plants as soon as she gets home.
moreExamples: When the bell rings, the students leave the classroom.
I'll call you before I leave the office.
After she finishes work, she goes to the gym.
As soon as he arrives, we'll start the meeting.
Until you apologize, I won't speak to you.
useCases.notes: After time conjunctions (when, as soon as, before, after), use Present Simple for future meaning.

useCases.title: Permanent Situations
useCases.mainExample: The sun rises in the east.
moreExamples: Water boils at 100Â°C.
Lions live in Africa.
The Earth orbits the Sun.
My parents live in Manchester.
She works as a teacher.
useCases.notes: Use Present Simple for facts and situations that are generally or permanently true.

useCases.title: Scheduled Events
useCases.mainExample: The train leaves at 6:30pm.
moreExamples: The film starts at 8 o'clock.
School begins on Monday.
The shop opens at 9am.
Her flight departs at midnight.
The concert finishes at 11pm.
useCases.notes: Use Present Simple for timetables and fixed schedules.

useCases.title: Actions Happening Now
useCases.mainExample: She is reading a book right now.
moreExamples: I'm working on a project at the moment.
They're having dinner.
He's talking on the phone.
We're watching TV.
The children are playing in the garden.
useCases.notes: Use Present Continuous for actions happening at the moment of speaking.

useCases.title: Temporary Situations
useCases.mainExample: I'm living with my parents until I find a flat.
moreExamples: She's working in London this month.
He's studying for his exams this week.
They're staying at a hotel for a few days.
I'm using my brother's car while mine is being repaired.
We're renting a house until our new one is ready.
useCases.notes: Use Present Continuous for temporary situations, even if not happening right now.

useCases.title: Future Arrangements
useCases.mainExample: I'm meeting Tom at 6pm tomorrow.
moreExamples: We're flying to Paris next week.
She's having dinner with her boss tonight.
They're getting married in June.
He's starting his new job on Monday.
I'm seeing the doctor this afternoon.
useCases.notes: Use Present Continuous for fixed personal arrangements in the near future.

useCases.title: Changing Situations
useCases.mainExample: The climate is getting warmer every year.
moreExamples: House prices are rising rapidly.
Technology is advancing quickly.
His English is improving.
The situation is becoming worse.
More people are buying electric cars.
useCases.notes: Use Present Continuous for changing or developing situations.

useCases.title: Unfinished Time Period
useCases.mainExample: I have lived here for five years.
moreExamples: She has worked at the company since 2020.
We've known each other for ten years.
He has been a teacher for twenty years.
They've lived in the same house all their lives.
I've studied English since I was a child.
useCases.notes: Use Present Perfect when the time period is unfinished and continues to now.

useCases.title: Life Experience (no specific time)
useCases.mainExample: I have visited Paris three times.
moreExamples: She has never eaten sushi.
Have you ever been to Japan?
He has read all the Harry Potter books.
We've seen that film before.
They've travelled to over 30 countries.
useCases.notes: Use Present Perfect for life experiences without mentioning when they happened.

useCases.title: Recent Actions with Present Results
useCases.mainExample: I've lost my keys. (I can't find them now)
moreExamples: She's broken her leg. (It's still broken)
He's gone to the shops. (He's not here now)
They've moved to London. (They live there now)
I've finished my homework. (It's done now)
The bus has left. (It's not here anymore)
useCases.notes: Use Present Perfect when a past action has a present result or is relevant now.

useCases.title: Actions Just Completed
useCases.mainExample: I've just finished my work.
moreExamples: She's just left the office.
We've just arrived home.
He's just called you.
They've just bought a new car.
The film has just started.
useCases.notes: Use 'just' with Present Perfect for very recent actions.

useCases.title: Duration Continuing to Now
useCases.mainExample: I've been working here for five years.
moreExamples: She's been studying English since 2020.
How long have you been waiting?
They've been living in Paris for ten years.
He's been playing tennis since he was a child.
We've been watching TV all evening.
useCases.notes: Use Present Perfect Continuous to emphasize the duration of an ongoing activity.

useCases.title: Recent Activity with Present Evidence
useCases.mainExample: I'm tired because I've been running.
moreExamples: She's sweating because she's been exercising.
The grass is wet because it's been raining.
His hands are dirty because he's been gardening.
They're exhausted because they've been working all day.
You look happy. What have you been doing?
useCases.notes: Use Present Perfect Continuous when there's visible evidence of a recent activity.

useCases.title: Completed Actions at Specific Past Time
useCases.mainExample: I saw that film yesterday.
moreExamples: She went to Paris last year.
He finished his degree in 2020.
We bought this house three years ago.
They visited us last month.
I met her at the party on Saturday.
useCases.notes: Use Past Simple for completed actions at a finished time in the past.

useCases.title: Sequence of Past Events
useCases.mainExample: I woke up, had breakfast, and went to work.
moreExamples: She opened the door, walked in, and sat down.
He turned on the TV, made some tea, and relaxed.
They arrived, checked in, and went to their room.
I finished work, caught the bus, and got home at 7pm.
We parked the car, bought tickets, and entered the museum.
useCases.notes: Use Past Simple for a series of completed actions in chronological order.

useCases.title: Past Habits (with 'used to')
useCases.mainExample: I used to play football every weekend.
moreExamples: She used to live in London.
We used to go camping every summer.
He used to smoke, but he quit.
They used to have a dog.
I didn't use to like vegetables.
useCases.notes: Use 'used to' + infinitive for past habits or states that are no longer true.

useCases.title: Background Action (interrupted by Past Simple)
useCases.mainExample: I was watching TV when the phone rang.
moreExamples: She was cooking dinner when her friends arrived.
While I was walking to work, I saw an accident.
He was reading a book when he fell asleep.
They were playing tennis when it started raining.
We were having lunch when the fire alarm went off.
useCases.notes: Use Past Continuous for the longer background action that was interrupted.

useCases.title: Two Simultaneous Past Actions
useCases.mainExample: While I was studying, my brother was playing video games.
moreExamples: She was cooking while he was setting the table.
I was working while you were sleeping.
They were talking while we were listening to music.
He was driving while she was reading the map.
The children were playing while the adults were chatting.
useCases.notes: Use Past Continuous for two actions happening at the same time in the past.

useCases.title: Specific Time in the Past
useCases.mainExample: At 8pm last night, I was having dinner.
moreExamples: This time yesterday, I was flying to New York.
At 3 o'clock, they were still working.
At midnight, she was still studying.
Yesterday morning at 10, we were in a meeting.
Last Saturday at 6pm, he was watching the match.
useCases.notes: Use Past Continuous to describe what was in progress at a specific past moment.

useCases.title: Earlier Past Action (before another past action)
useCases.mainExample: When I arrived, they had already left.
moreExamples: She had finished her work before she went home.
By the time we got to the station, the train had departed.
He had never seen snow before he moved to Canada.
After they had eaten dinner, they watched TV.
I had read the book before I saw the film.
useCases.notes: Use Past Perfect for the earlier of two past actions. The later action uses Past Simple.

useCases.title: Reported Speech (backshift from Present Perfect)
useCases.mainExample: She said she had finished her homework.
moreExamples: He told me he had lived there for ten years.
They said they had never been to Spain.
She explained that she had lost her keys.
He mentioned that he had already eaten.
They told us they had just arrived.
useCases.notes: Use Past Perfect in reported speech when the original statement was in Present Perfect.

useCases.title: Unrealized Past Hopes/Expectations
useCases.mainExample: I had hoped to see you at the party. (but I didn't)
moreExamples: She had expected to pass the exam. (but she didn't)
We had planned to go on holiday. (but we couldn't)
They had intended to call you. (but they forgot)
He had wanted to be a doctor. (but he became a teacher)
I had thought the meeting was today. (but it was yesterday)
useCases.notes: Use Past Perfect with verbs like hope, expect, plan, intend for unfulfilled past intentions.

useCases.title: Duration Before a Past Point
useCases.mainExample: I was tired because I had been working all day.
moreExamples: She was exhausted because she had been running for an hour.
The ground was wet because it had been raining.
He was sweating because he had been exercising.
They were hungry because they had been waiting for ages.
My eyes hurt because I had been reading for hours.
useCases.notes: Use Past Perfect Continuous for the duration of an activity up to a past point.

useCases.title: Showing Cause and Effect in Past
useCases.mainExample: He failed the test because he hadn't been studying.
moreExamples: She knew London well because she had been living there for years.
The roads were icy because it had been snowing all night.
He was out of breath because he had been running.
They were late because they had been stuck in traffic.
I was confused because I hadn't been paying attention.
useCases.notes: Use Past Perfect Continuous to explain reasons for past situations.

useCases.title: Predictions (opinions about the future)
useCases.mainExample: I think it will rain tomorrow.
moreExamples: She'll probably pass her exam.
The team will win the match.
He won't like that restaurant.
I don't think they'll arrive on time.
The economy will improve next year.
useCases.notes: Use 'will' for predictions based on opinion, not evidence.

useCases.title: Spontaneous Decisions (made at moment of speaking)
useCases.mainExample: I'll have the chicken, please.
moreExamples: It's cold. I'll close the window.
The phone's ringing. I'll answer it.
Don't worry, I'll help you.
I'm hungry. I'll make a sandwich.
I'll buy some milk on the way home.
useCases.notes: Use 'will' for decisions made at the moment of speaking, not planned in advance.

useCases.title: Promises and Offers
useCases.mainExample: I'll call you tomorrow, I promise.
moreExamples: Don't worry, I'll be there on time.
I'll help you with your homework.
We'll pay you back next week.
I'll never forget you.
I'll always love you.
useCases.notes: Use 'will' to make promises and offers.

useCases.title: Plans and Intentions
useCases.mainExample: I'm going to study medicine at university.
moreExamples: We're going to buy a new car next month.
She's going to apply for the job.
They're going to get married next year.
He's going to learn Spanish.
I'm not going to watch TV tonight.
useCases.notes: Use 'going to' for plans and intentions decided before speaking.

useCases.title: Predictions with Evidence
useCases.mainExample: Look at those clouds! It's going to rain!
moreExamples: Watch out! You're going to fall!
Be careful! The glass is going to break!
Look at the traffic. We're going to be late.
She's not feeling well. She's going to be sick.
The match is 3-0. They're going to lose.
useCases.notes: Use 'going to' for predictions based on present evidence.

useCases.title: Fixed Personal Arrangements
useCases.mainExample: I'm meeting Tom at 6pm tomorrow.
moreExamples: We're flying to Paris next week.
She's having dinner with her boss tonight.
They're getting married in June.
He's starting his new job on Monday.
I'm seeing the dentist this afternoon.
useCases.notes: Use Present Continuous for fixed arrangements, especially with other people.

useCases.title: Timetables and Schedules
useCases.mainExample: The train leaves at 6:30pm.
moreExamples: The film starts at 8 o'clock.
School begins on Monday.
The shop opens at 9am tomorrow.
Her flight departs at midnight.
The concert finishes at 11pm.
useCases.notes: Use Present Simple for official timetables and fixed schedules.
